contribution_types.label: Contribution Type
contribution_types.definition: The main contribution of the paper to the field of human-AI decision-making

options.label: Algorithmic contributions
options.definition: new AI/ML algorithms, models, or computational approaches, very specific thing

options.label: Empirical contributions
options.definition: experimental findings, user studies, and observational research results

options.label: Theoretical contributions
options.definition: conceptual frameworks, conceptual models, and theories

options.label: Methodological contributions
options.definition: new research methods, evaluation frameworks, analytical approaches, and design guidelines/principles

options.label: System/Artifact contributions
options.definition: implemented systems, tools, interfaces, and design solutions

options.label: Dataset/Benchmark contributions
options.definition: new datasets, benchmarks, and evaluation resources

application_domains.label: Application Domain
application_domains.definition: The field or domain where the research is applied

options.label: Healthcare / Medicine / Surgery
options.definition: public health, nursing, childcare, clinical, medicine, healthcare, surgery, therapy

options.label: Finance / Business / Economy
options.definition: finance/investment/loan, business/trading/shopping/marketing, blockchain/bitcoin

options.label: Education / Teaching / Research
options.definition: schooling, teaching, academia, research, data analysis, assessments, science

options.label: Law / Policy / Governance
options.definition: criminal/law/legal/justice; politics/government/democracy, policymaking, campaign

options.label: Software / Systems / Security
options.definition: smart home, programming, software engineering, cloud computing, databases, privacy, internet infrastructure

options.label: Transportation / Mobility / Planning
options.definition: city/smart city; driving, traffic, logistics, travel, freight, navigation, flight, aviation

options.label: Manufacturing / Industry / Automation
options.definition: manufacturing, supply chain, logistics, robotics, automation, resource allocation

options.label: Environment / Resources / Energy
options.definition: wate, food,  agriculture, fishery, water, food, energy, electricity, environment

options.label: Defense / Military / Emergency
options.definition: homeland security, military, disaster prediction, emergency response, surveillance

options.label: Media / Communication / Entertainment
options.definition: press/journalism/writing, sport, game/entertainment, social media/social network, tourism

options.label: Design / Creativity / Architecture
options.definition: design, creativity, architecture, art, innovation, user experience

options.label: Everyday / Employment / Public Service
options.definition: hiring, admissions, caregiving, daycare, social good, public sector, management, everyday tasks, renting, image classifaction related to everyday tasks

options.label: Generic / Abstract / Domain-agnostic
options.definition: General purposes or abstract context; general image classification

ai_roles.label: AI Roles
ai_roles.definition: The role that AI systems play in the decision-making process

options.label: Analyzing
options.definition: Processes complex information to give it structure and clarity
options.description: (pattern/action) recognizer, biomarker identifier, (human behavior/prognostic) modeler, (treatment effect) estimator, risk assessment tool, summarizer, (information/knowledge) extractor, report generator, information/option provider, planner, analyzer

options.label: Forecasting
options.description: (counterfactual/risk) predictor, forecaster, mortality prediction model, (image) classifier, (skin cancer) detector
options.definition: Uses current and historical data to forecast what will happen in the future. It answers the question, "What's next?"

options.label: Explaining
options.definition: Translates opaque processes into human-readable justifications. "Why did this happen?"
options.description: explainer, reasoner

options.label: Advising
options.definition: Actively provides recommendations or guidance for the human to consider
options.description: recommender, AI teacher, (suggestion/portfolio) generator, (robo-) advisor, tutor, coach, guide, curriculum designer, advice interpreter, decision-making model/algo/system

options.label: Collaborating
options.definition: works alongside a human as a partner in a dynamic, interactive process
options.description: collaborator, AI partner, teammate, human-agent team member, hybrid partner, complementary learner, co-pilot, interactive agent, shared autonomy system, assistant/supplement, collaboration aid, conversational agent (CA), chatbot, virtual assistant, dialogue manager, health chatbots

options.label: Executing
options.definition: acts independently to perform a task or make a decision delegated by a human
options.description: task performer/delegatee, assigner/matcher, actor, agent, (workflow) optimizer, allocator, scheduler, controller, task automator, resource generator, automated (trader/negotiator), (game/autonomous) player, strategic agent, policy generator, decision-maker, (policy) learner

options.label: Monitoring
options.definition: Monitors a system's real-time performance, status, and safety
options.description: (trajectory/policy) evaluator, supervisor, overseer, (quality/reliability) assessor, performance monitor, system health diagnostician

options.label: Auditing
options.definition: Checks and validates a system against established rules, ethics, and standards
options.description: (fairness/policy) auditor, ethical verifier, (bias/discrimination) detector, formal modeler

human_roles.label: Human Roles
human_roles.definition: The role that humans play in the decision-making process

options.label: Decision-maker
options.definition: Individuals who engage with AI to make decisions, collaborate, learn, delegate, or guide the system’s improvement
options.description: decision-maker, investigator, user, collaborator, learner, delegator

options.label: Decision-subject
options.definition: Individuals upon whom a decision is made and who are directly affected by the outcome
options.description: (cancer) patients, (loan/job) applicants, defendant / inmates, candidate / students, customer / consumer, decision subjects (defendants, citizens, authors...)

options.label: Developer
options.definition: Technical professionals who design, build, and maintain the AI system
options.description: AI (developers/software engineers), data scientist/engineer, ML model engineers/practitioners, (system) designers, database administrators, technical experts, researcher

options.label: Guardian
options.definition: Individuals and institutions that set the rules, policies, and ethical guardrails for AI systems
options.description: regulator, policy-maker, government, (independent) auditor, AI ethicist, moral philosophers, research ethics committees, lawyers, judges, courts, parole board, governing body, supervisor, evaluator, analyst/auditor

options.label: Knowledge provider
options.definition: People who provide the specialized data, expertise, or judgment used to train and validate the AI
options.description: (domain/subject matter/medical/legal) experts, annotator, labeler, manual coder, survey participant, crowd workers, human subjects, human as inspiration, human as benchmark / guide, teacher

options.label: Stakeholder
options.definition: The broader community or groups indirectly impacted by the AI's deployment and societal consequence
options.description: community, citizens, public, families, employees, company stakeholders, (vulnerable/protected) groups, society

ai_influence.label: AI Influence on humans
ai_influence.definition: The degree to which AI influences the final decision outcome

options.label: Alter decision outcomes
options.definition: improving accuracy, improving speed / response rate, reducing speed, achieving complementary human-AI performance, changing decision, following AI recommendation, improving performance, increasing decision quality

options.label: Change trust
options.definition: trust (except for moral trust), reliance, aversion, faith in AI’s capabilities

options.label: Change cognitive demands
options.definition: Cognitive load, human effort, burden recall, retention, decision time, skills, ...

options.label: Change affective-perceptual
options.definition: confidence, feelings, satisfaction, ...

options.label: Restrict human agency
options.definition: autonomy, agency, control, ...

options.label: Shift responsibility
options.definition: responsibility, blame, accountability, moral trust, ...

options.label: Shape ethical norms
options.definition: reducing bias, ensuring fairness, detecting direct biases, detecting indirect biases, increasing agreement with model biases, increasing acceptance of unethical advice, reinforcing perceived fairness, ...

options.label: Update AI competence
options.definition: Human influence on system robustness and perceived competence
options.description: performance, accuracy, interpretability, returning predictable outputs, improving AI performance, keeping transparent, preferring/prioritizing X, ...

options.label: Change AI responses through feedback
options.definition: Direct ways humans refine and shape AI outputs
options.description: refining prompts, learning from feedback, providing desired information to trust AI, human-adjusted refinements (providing corrections, clarifications), increasing depth of information

options.label: Shape AI for accountability
options.definition: Humans have limited influence on the decision

decision_types.label: Decision Type
decision_types.definition: The category of decision being made in the context studied

options.label: Individual
options.definition: decisions decisions made by a single person for themselves
options.description: personal diabetes management, purchase products, accepting AI shopping advice, lane-changing,  select fashion items/movies/university, travel planning, farmers’ planting decisions, program library selection,  creative support tools

options.label: Operational
options.definition: decisions embedded in day-to-day routines and practices
options.description: clinical diagnosis, coordinating connected fleets, loan approval, hiring/firing, admissions, resource allocation, policy development, grade students, identify harmful posts, production scheduling, farmers’ planting decisions, load shedding, code review,  military operators

options.label: Organizational
options.definition: decisions made within or on behalf of organizations
options.description: emergency department management, COVID vaccine allocation, supply chain management,  aviation operations, manage workforce, recruit students, game management, manage suppliers/retailers, code review, emergency facility planning

options.label: Institutional
options.definition: decisions that establish standards or norm
options.description: governance frameworks and legitimacy of algorithmic decisions in markets/public services/schools, social media filtering, digital twins,  climate forecasts, develop defensive strategies under attack,  air defense planning
